comments.commentBody: Jules is right. More people voted for Democrats for Congress last time around than Republicans but gerrymandering keeps the house in the GOP's hands for now.

jules:

Republicans won their majorities in districts DEMOCRATS had gerrymandered to suit their own interests. Now that Republicans hold majorities in so many legislatures, Democrats seem to expect that we have an obligation to draw districts that benefit Democrats.

Life doesn't work that way, and you might consider asking your own candidates to come up with better arguments, or you have NO hope of doing to us what we did to you (after you did it, for many years, to us).
Thanks to extremely successful gerrymandering of House districts.

Over 80% of the population live in cities and keeps growing.  Not good news for Republicans.  Out here in farm country, it takes fewer people to farm and their kids are leaving as soon as they go away to college and don't return.

Dana #22,

Thanks for stopping by! A favorite memory is our coffee down in Santa Cruz when you spread out your work on the Sun Bin problem. Dozens and dozens of pages of detailed, organized notes. I was amazed.

I really like the Approximator approach. As for a separate category -- for what I had in mind I think it depends on intent.

I was attempting to outline the classic worldviews represented by umpires calling balls and strikes:
1. "I call them as they are."
2. "I call them as I see 'em."
3. "They aren't anything until I call 'em."

The Approximator could probably facilitate thinking in each one of these. Perhaps the approach is particularly useful for the 3rd view. I personally really like the idea of working from extremes.
If you're solving on paper, make teeny tiny letters.
If you're using Crosswords Plus tap SYM in the lower left of the keyboard or tap-and-hold on square until an entry window pops up.
If I were solving on paper and were in no rush, I'd paste a little square of tinfoil in each Ag square.
How do I enter both the A and the G in the same square?

None of these players are here by accident.  You have a good mix of old school leadership coupled with patient development driven by sabermetrics.  Baseball will continue to evolve, but some how stay the same.  What a game.
Are you living in an  alternate universe where the Indians ended up beating the Cubs?

The Cubs will never win. Ever. They are cursed forever. Only a cursed team could blow a 4-run lead in game 7 and lose it in extra innings. I think we'd all be better off if the Cubs moved to Montreal and the Ricketts demolish Wrigley and turn it into a park. A fitting end to the world's biggest losers. Spare us the suffering and end this idiotic franchise now.
wHA(t) is eSP(f)?

and Elke
the game is ON AGAIN OFF AGAIN (rain)
Got the rebus from STEERAGE (had ST-ER-E ). Reminded me of my arrival on this continent early 50's. The boat was not a cruiseliner.
Nice to see Phil ESPOsito from the Soo in CANAda.
CALF'S -foot jelly is known by us as "p'tsha" (actually not a favourite).
The pic with Deb's comment says "baggage handler works on a jam". His hands are in his pocket, is he using eSP(f) ?
Game back on.
Had to resort to tablet to comment. Problems as others have noted..

DD, you bring up an important point. The biggest republican donors (outside of the Texans) tend to live in cities--the Koch brothers, Adelson, and the Borgias of Long Island, the Mercers. Interesting that they don't practice what they preach in their propaganda.

Dear Elizabeth:
Please do not take me literally. Let me explain. It is not apathy to politics I am advocating. As a lifelong Democrat since'60 (JFK), and a native New Yorker, I am preaching to the choir. When Nixon won NY in '72, I voted for McGovern. When Reagan won in '84, I voted for Mondale. I live in a state I am proud to say has voted correctly.

Next week Hillary will take NY in a landslide. The state of Washington will go to Hillary. That being the case, I have never missed an election. Whether my candidate is behind or way ahead, I vote. Always have, always will until I'm six feet under.

But when it comes to Republicans, I have no say. It is not my party, so it us up to Republicans to wise-up, to stop listening to right-wing hate radio and FOX "News". If they don't there's nothing I can do. It is the Republican rank and file which deserves a good shellacking come next Tuesday. It is up to Republicans who need to listen to leaders like the Bushes and the Romney's, people who I may not agree with but know how to play the game fairly. They understand the danger Trump brings to their party. He has so lowered the bar it will take years to recover their reputation after putting up a outright demagogue and know-nothing as their candidate. When Republicans realize how ridiculous they look maybe they'll change. But, and this was the point I was trying to make previously, there's nothing I can do to change their minds.

DD
Manhattan

DD
Manhattan

Dear Colenso:
Trump's apparel decision is two-fold. It is his uniform, he is a billionaire from NYC and he wants to project that. I'll give him this. Whereas other candidates will dress to suit the place their politicking, although they would never wear those outfits were they not in some cornfield in Iowa, Trump at least is not hypocritical. But the other side of the coin is this: Trump finds wearing anything but a power suit demeaning. He thinks most of his supporters are a bunch of hicks. He normally wouldn't be caught dead associating with them. If you can't do something for Trump, he has no use for you.

To Trump, "flyover country" is something he's always abided by. Until he was a candidate, Trump always flew over the people he now claims he wants to help. He's never been to any poor rural sections of this country until now. After 70 years on this planet Trump has never cared about what happens to the working poor, except to provide his projects with cheap non-Union work.

That is the irony here. Trump has done nothing to support Labor in any fashion yet he has the white working and non-working class vote supporting him. How sad and pathetic is that? Trump has managed to get people who he disdains to vote for him. There is the work of a true con artist.

DD
Manhattan

Republicans used to win in states like New York. Nelson Rockefeller was our governor, Jacob Javitts our Senator. In '84, Reagan won New York. But those days are long gone. Somewhere over the course of time, Republicans decided to appeal to a different segment of the populace. The Southern strategy of Nixon ballooned into a Bible Belt evangelical movement which had no room for ideas on how to solve problems in urban neighborhoods. Cities suffered from white flight to the suburbs, to what they thought was a better life. Ignoring the problem didn't help, it only further pushed it under the carpet. Absence did nothing to solve anything, and so it only festered.

To make matters worse, Republicans began nominating candidates who were so out of touch with urban areas the only time you saw them in a metropolis like NY was when they came to beg for money from big donors.

Now the irony is that the GOP for the first time in a long time has as its candidate the ultimate city dweller, someone so out of place in a rural setting no one has ever seen their candidate in casual clothes, and they never will. Yet here in his hometown, we who know him best will vote for Hillary in a landslide. He not only has no redeeming values for solving urban problems, he was the cause of many of them. As for what the GOP will do after yet another defeat? Frankly, who cares.

DD
Manhattan

Democrats do use emotional appeals also, but the difference is that Democratic policies actually help most people (including most wealthy people), while the Republicans policies help only the wealthy.
And yet Kansas will still be sending two Senators to congress, hence the structural advantage Republicans exploit in our political system.
Sean:  You are right on target.  Wish you weren't  -  very sad how the voters viewed Carter and Kerry!

No, her campaign has not. That ad aired only once...and there was a lot of negative press about it.

Johnson did not fabricate the first Gulf of Tonkin incident....but most likely exaggerated it. The second? Yeah, it was a fabrication.

Clinton supporters have revived the 1964 political TV ad with the little girl pulling petals off of a daisy, only to be caught in a nuclear blast. That commercial was first run back then in support of Lyndon Johnson, who sought to defeat the allegedly "trigger happy" Barry Goldwater.

Johnson won that election by a landslide, and was inaugurated to his first full elected term in January 1965. By that summer, the Johnson Administration fabricated the Golf of Tonkin incident, and what followed was eight years of American conducted war in Southeast Asia. About 40,000 Americans died in that war, and countless hundreds of thousands were injured. Millions served, most involuntarily through being drafted.

I don't know what Barry Goldwater would have done had he been elected. But the Peace and Sanity candidate certainly created a lot of distressed Viet Nam era veterans, who fought bravely in a doomed cause. Eventually, the North prevailed, Viet Nam was unified, and is now a most favored US trade partner.

Veterans recognize trigger happy "send in the troops" candidates. Perhaps, due to a lack of natural testosterone, Mrs Clinton feels she must not be seen as militarily meek. And does so over veterans dead and broken bodies.

Except in reality, rural voters are more dependent on government programs than urban dwellers. WIthout farm subsidies, federally funded highways, dams and other infrastructure, use of public lands for fees far below market rates, etc., much of rural America, especially in the West, could never be profitably farmed, mined, etc.

Actually, only about 62.7% of the population lives in cities (U.S. census), while the rest live in suburbs, exurbs and rural areas. That 80.7% number combines suburbs and exurbs with canyon-dwellers, leaving about 19.3% living in rural areas alone. This is why the news is actually great for Republicans, because they outnumber Democrats in many venues outside of true urban areas -- it's primarily why the House is solidly Republican, as are about two-thirds of our statehouses.

The continued diversification of the US spells doom for the GOP. Their grasp on rural voters is their ace card and it is getting tattered. High density urban centers will continue to grow in political power to the detriment of the evangelicals and conservatives.
The Hart-Celler Immigration Act, enacted in '68 has greatly changed the demographic makeup of the American population, as immigrants entering the United States under the new legislation come increasingly from countries in Asia, Africa and Latin America, as opposed to Europe. The white vote as a power point is fading and as it does, so goes the GOP.
Perhaps it is because India is a lot poorer compared to the west. It is a democracy, and the government will act if there are enough people demanding it.

I live in Delhi, having relocated after living almost two decades in the West, including Sweden, where pollution is taken very seriously.

The government is spineless where curbing pollution is concerned. Besides curbing the fires mentioned in the article, the dust from construction activity (sand, cement) is not controlled....construction companies are allowed to leave mounds of material in the open, in heavily populated areas, which contributes to dust with the slightest wind.

Let's not forget the status conscious Delhites. With blocked roads and poisonous levels of pollution, they still want to buy large cars, mostly SUVs, when one cannot even enjoy driving those cars the way they were engineered to be, either due to roads or having a driver.

The people need to demand more. And I may need to relocate back.

We have the same calamity in South Louisiana with the burning of sugarcane fields in autumn. The Federal law that forbids this practice has a provision for exceptions which all cultivators are routinely granted.  However it is regulated by allowing calendar slots by location so that burning is evenly distributed geographically over a three month period. Still, the particulates are directly perceptible as are the plumes of smoke from the air and from the height of major bridges but to the untrained eye at ground level the problem is not apparent. There is no systematic measurement of the health and environmental impacts of sugarcane field burning which must be considerable.

Should.

But won't.

We have had an engaged, principled and civil President who has attempted to work with Republicans many for eight years. The Republicans vowed to make him e a one term president before he was even inaugurated in 2008 (even as the worse financial disaster since the Great Depression was playing out), and they have done nothing but obstruct everything he has tired to do. Enough with this "both sides" claptrap.

"We are short staffed, we are desperately short on support staff"
Nobody is really saying the care is that bad when it is able to be had. It's getting it timely and consistently that's the problem. Every va facility is different as is every other hospital. I wasn't impressed with mine, tho that was many years ago. I stopped going because I got my own employer benefits and it seemed to me there were guys in more need than I was, so one less strain on the system. We had good facilities on Fort Hood though. And like I said that was like 18yrs ago. But the VA in my home town, wasn't great at all.
Thanks for your service, both to the country and the veterans

Should Trump succeed in getting elected, he surely will renege on whatever promises Veterans believe he has made to them.  If vets feel abandoned now, just wait until a President Trump is “looking after” their interests.  By choosing a billionaire Republican business con artist to be their champion, they would get to see what real abandonment looks like.

Chesty Puller, Audie Murphy, and Alvin York must be spinning in their graves to think that modern American soldiers actually believe the party of "shock and awe" that took them into the Iraq War based on lies about weapons of mass destruction that never existed, as told by Republicans Bush, Cheney, Rumsfeld and the neo cons.   Stupid is as stupid does.

I really do wonder how they felt at the time while serving.  Were all political thoughts suppressed then released now?  Countless ordinary citizens, along with their elected officials were excoriated for opposing the war and denounced as Un American and Un Patriotic.  It seems now convenient that DST should be their annointed candidate seeing as he ran as far away from the military as possible save some upper class finishing school.  It sounds like some of these folks want to go back into combat, and Trump is the likeliest one to fulfill that wish.

My reply corrects typos from having made the original entry half in my sleep from my phone.
"They are supporting a man who diminishes their worth by not paying taxes into a system that trained these brave men and women solders; that paid them, that continues to support them and their families--not only for the enlistees, but also career military -- that gives them benefits, a livelihood, an education, and a career path. All of that comes from our taxes.

Yes, so smart, aren't they? Support a man for president who treats you with contempt and a complete disregard for your hard work, dedication, and devotion to this nation -- conceived in liberty and dedicated to the proposition that we are all created equal and deserve the best this country and its leaders can offer.

they are supporting a man who diminishes their worth by not paying taxes into a system that trained these brave men and women solders, that paid them, that continues to support them and their families--both for the enlistees, career military, that gives them benefits. Yes smart Support a man for president who treats you with contempt.

How's that working for you?

Are you sure we are doing more for vets than we have ever done, or is this just PR? There are long VA lines, many deployments in wars that never end, and always more deployments threatened.

The politicians, the think tanks, the foreign policy gurus, and the brass are using up the troops like hardware, and they seem not be sensitive to the limits of a limited professional army. We all sit back and watch these de facto mercenaries prosecute political wars that have only a tenuous connection to our national security. Is it any wonder that the grunts are broken and dejected?
Exactly.
I'm an US Army Vet and I vote. I am not fooled by the Con man that is Trump. Come on people, be serious.
